1. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:

Pastoria Energy Facility (PEF) employees are committed to conducting their operation in a safe and responsible manner.  They will conduct operations in compliance with applicable industry standards, Cal-OSHA?s Process Safety Management Standard and EPA?s Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions. PEF personnel will be trained and prepared to respond to operational emergencies safely and effectively, minimizing the risk to personnel, the public, and the community-at-large. They will ensure that their emergency response plans and capabilities are compatible with the local emergency response agencies.

2. The facility and regulated substances handled:

The Pastoria Energy Facility is approximately 40 acres in size and is located approximately 30 miles south of Bakersfield, California and six miles east of I-5. PEF will produce as much as 750 megawatts of electric power using three natural gas-fueled combustion turbines in concert with two steam turbines. Hot exhaust gases are recycled to generate steam, which is used to generate additional power in two steam turbines. This configuration makes the facility as much as forty percent more efficient than most existing gas-fired power plants.  In addition to relying exclusively upon clean natural gas, PEF will be equipped with advanced emissions control systems to significantly reduce emissions. 

Ammonia is used to reduce the nitrogen oxide emissions, which improves air quality.  The emissions control operations include two 30,000 gallon storage tanks that will each contain a maximum of 24,000 gallons of anhydrous ammonia [Note: A maximum fill of 24,000 gallons is 80% of tank capacity which is the administrative control that PEF has instituted in their procedures]. 

The anhydrous ammonia is delivered to the site by truck. Anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the truck to the storage tank by means of a truck-mounted pump. Liquid anhydrous ammonia (99.5 to 99.

7 percent concentration) is maintained in the storage tanks that will be allowed to follow ambient air temperature. Tank pressure will correspond to saturated ammonia conditions at tank temperature. During periods of low ambient temperature where the ammonia tank pressure drops below the required ammonia vapor supply pressure, an electric vaporizer will be used to maintain sufficient tank pressure to meet the required delivery pressure. 

The regulated ammonia supply from the storage tank is mixed with air provided by air blowers on the ammonia dilution skid. The ammonia/air mixture is forwarded to the ammonia injection grid located in the hot gas exhaust stream upstream of the catalyst module in the Heat Recovery Steam Generator (NOx reduction process).

3. Accidental release prevention program:

The facility?s accidental release prevention program is modeled after and in compliance with federal and state programs for managing hazardous chemical processes. It meets the requirements of Cal-OSHA? Process Safety Management standard, EPA?s Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP).

Specific elements of the program include: Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor Safety, Contractor and Visitor Orientation, Pre-Job Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Code of Safe Practices, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Planning and Response, and Compliance Audits.

Specific accident prevention steps include the following programs, procedures, and practices:
o Initial and annual training in PSM
o Integrity testing and inspection of process equipment/piping
o Employee participation in the MOC process and PHA.
o Unrestricted access to process safety information by employees and contractors.
o Operator training program which includes initial, on the job training, and refresher training and demonstration of competency.
o

Hot Work Permit procedure
o Confined Space Entry procedure
o Lockout/Tagout/Try Procedure
o Code of Safe Work Practices
o Respiratory Protection Program
o HAZCOM program
o Procedure for opening process equipment and piping
o Controlled/limited access to facility and process areas.
o Periodic training on selected health, safety, and environmental topics.
o Emergency Action & Response Plan for all plant personnel.  
o Contractor Safety Selection and Monitoring Policy

4. The five-year accident history:

PEF has had no reportable accidents or incidences that resulted in injury, environmental damage, or off-site impact related to the ammonia system/process.

5. The emergency response program:

The emergency response program/plan is written and posted in a dedicated binder which is located in the Administration Building Control Room. The plan describes the evacuation procedures, the emergency actions to take, individual responsibilities during an emergency, and the appropriate notifications and contacts to make for specific types of emergency events.  Plant evacuations are initiated by activating an audible signal, and communications through employee radios. The plan is reviewed and coordinated with the Kern County Fire Department on a periodic basis.

Emergency Action and Response training is conducted at least annually with all PEF employees. Training includes the specific responsibilities and duties that each PEF employee should take in the event of an emergency. Training will also include coordination, involvement and emergency drill exercises with potential local emergency responders (Kern County Fire Department and Hazardous Materials Division, and the Hazardous Material Contractor selected by PEF.

Maintenance and testing of the emergency equipment is scheduled in the facility?s computerized maintenance management system and performed by the maintenance personnel at the appropriate interval.  

In addition, PEF?s ammonia system also includes area sensors for the

detection of ammonia leaks, a manual activated deluge system over the ammonia storage tanks with secondary containment and area fire water monitors. 

6. Planned changes to improve safety:

Planned changes to improve safety include implementing PHA recommendations and continuing the effort to review/update the facility?s RMP and PSM programs and operating procedures. 

A brief summary of PHA recommended action items include, but not limited to, the following:
o Conduct thorough Pre-Startup Safety Review after construction of ammonia system is complete and prior to receiving ammonia.
o Conduct ?walkdown? of ammonia system in conformance with ANSI K61.1 and CalARP Guidance Program for Seismic   
Assessments.
o Implement Administrative Procedures recommended by PHA, such as heavy and excavation equipment restrictions/limitations in proximity to live ammonia system components.
